bibl.title: Letter from Carlos O. Coello to Henry Rose Carter, July 25, 1923

div1.p: Coello reports on shipping between South America and Australia and Asia. He notes that sanitation in Guayaquil has improved and discusses disease cases.

div1.head: Letter from Carlos O. Coello to Henry Rose Carter, July 25, 1923
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Guayaquil, July 25, 1923
Dr H. R. Carter, Asst. Surgeon General,
U S Public Health Service
Washington, D C
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I am ashamed of the manner in which
I have carried out your instructions in regard to the systems
of transportation between the W. Coast of Sout America and Australia
and the South East of Asia. I am still waiting for some of the
answers of people whom I wrote in search of precise, reliable
information, to be well vouchered before you; but spite
of my complains for their lack of promptness, it is im-
possible to get them yet, and I have decided to wait
no longer.

The truth is, as I told you in my previous
letter, that a few boats, japanese some of them, run from
Australia to the Northern Coast of Chile and the main ports
of Peru, carrying, not coal as I said, but wheat for Chile
and I think same thing for Peru, at large intervals. To Ecuador,
boats (steam and sail) used to come loaded with coal, but
not latably; the last of them came to Guayaquil about
four years ago. More or less the same can be said of
the Colombian Coast; but neither those to Chile and Peru
C1
B21
nor those to Ecuador and Colombia go back
directly by the same route. Some of them go to Bal-
boa and San Francisco and then to Australia or
Asia, while other go first to Europe via Canal.

I suppose you know this already, but
I wish to show you that I have ocupied myself
on your “encargo”, and that I regreat my having
not been able to write you sooner and in
a more conciencious way.

Sanitary conditions in Guayaquil
have dicedely improved, and plague is going
in full retreat, throw the system of Campains
that you condensed in two words and recomend us
so much when you were here: “to built out and
to feed out the rats, out”.

Another case of Hemorrhagic Fever was
reported last April (I think); officially, and I sent
a full description of it to the Bureau. Specimens of
abdominal viscerae were sent by me to the Ancon Hospital
Laboratory: No organism was found.

Wishing you happiness, and with regards
for the Señorita, I am most cordially yours
